title: Sri Lanka stocks fall for the seventh day on weak sentiments
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s stocks slipped 0.54 percent on Wednesday (01) for the seventh straight session as on week sentiments, a market analyst said.
The All Share Price Index (ASPI) closed 43.40 points down at 8,064.69 on Wednesday.
“The market is moving on the same sentiment, they didn’t react much today for tax hike because they are waiting for the rest of the taxes,” a top market analyst said.
The analyst previously said there’s a lot of uncertainty in the market stemming from the questions on the 21st amendment.
Though higher taxes are good for state finances and an IMF deal it will hit earnings.
The more liquid S&P SL20 index slipped 0.89 percent or 23.95 points to 2,655.38.
Investors however did expect a new budget with new revenue measures under Prime Minister Wickremesinghe.
The market has gained 6 percent in May so far following a loss of 23 percent in April and 14.5 percent in March.
The market has lost 34 percent so far this year after being one of the world’s best stock markets with an 80 percent return last year when large volumes of money were printed.
Trade controls were also slammed giving profits to the so-called ‘import substitution cronies’.
The daily market turnover was 1.2 billion rupees, more than half of this year’s average daily turnover of 3.9 billion rupees.
Sri Lanka’s sovereign default has already led it to restricted/selective default rating by rating agencies and weighed on investor sentiment.
Investors are also concerned over the steep fall of the rupee from 200 to 370 levels so far in 2022.
Foreign investors bought a net 20 million rupees worth of shares this week. The market has witnessed a total foreign outflow of 1.1 billion rupees so far this year.
On Wednesday, the All Share Price Index was dragged down mainly by Expolanka, which fell 2.54 percent to 210.7 rupees a share.
Commercial Bank fell 1.30 percent to 53.2 rupees a share while DFCC bank slipped 5 percent to 36.10 rupees a share (Colombo/Jun01/2022)
